body: WHEN Andrea M. Biggs, a painter, and her husband, Timothy, an anthropologist, arrived in New York from Massachusetts last year, they were hoping to rent an inexpensive but spacious apartment in lower Manhattan. To their dismay, they could find no such apartment. SoHo, TriBeCa, Greenwich Village and the East Village were crammed with people looking
title: BROOKLYN RENTS LURE ARTISTS

body: A 25-year-old Brooklyn man, who some black leaders say was beaten by the transit police two weeks ago after he was arrested for scrawling graffiti on a subway station wall, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital. Black activists described his death as the latest example of ''racially motivated police violence.'' The cause of the death of the man,
title: DEATH STIRS POLICE BURTALITY CHARGES

body: THE vaulted ceiling over the sanctuary of a 158-year-old landmark church near Washington Square in the Greenwich Village Historic District will be the first project financed by a new loan fund set up to preserve historic buildings. The Historic Preservation Fund Inc. is lending $45,000 to do the work in the Washington Square Methodist Church at 135
title: PRESERVATION FUND MAKE ITS FIRST LOAN

body: WALKING tours of New York have come a long way since 10 years ago, when such institutions as the Municipal Art Society, the Museum of the City of New York and the Friends of Cast Iron Architecture began to take New Yorkers on ordered routes through the city's history and architecture. Today, it is possible to spend almost any weekend scrutinizing
title: NEW YORK'S SIDEWALKS: A CHOICE OF TOURS

body: LITHOGRAPHS One can hardly think of a 19th-century sleigh ride without having Currier & Ives spring to mind. This prolific firm of lithographers flourished between 1835 and 1890, and their work went far beyond sleigh rides; it encompassed an all-embracing view of America during those years that the nation emerged from a rural to an industrial
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Artistic Exchange June 8 - A gala evening of dance sponsored by the Danish-American Society will begin at 8 P.M. with a performance at Carnegie Hall in which the Martha Graham Dance Company shares billing with Peter Martins and soloists of the Royal Danish
title: Future Events; Spring Frolics

body: Listed below are some forthcoming tours of homes, apartments and offices in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Connecticut and on Long Island. All tours are open to the public, and proceeds will benefit charities and civic groups. May 20. A self-guided tour of gardens and eight historic homes built between 1840 and 1882 in Mystic, Conn. Included will be three
title: FORTHCOMING TOURS OF HOMES IN REGION

body: They are unlikely spots for excellence - two junior high schools situated on blocks surrounded by burned-out tenements and abandoned lots. One sits in the shadow of the parachute jump at Coney Island, the other in a neighborhood that has become synonomous with urban blight, the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. But these two schools are more than oases
title: 2 'MAGNET SCHOOLS' STRIVE TO STAY THE BEST IN CITY

body: Brooklyn Jumps the Gun On Honoring Its Women L ady Deborah Moody laid out the Gravesend section of Brooklyn in the 1640's in four squares, still apparent through the modern grid. Margaret Sanger's first clinic was in Brownsville until the police jailed her. Mary White Ovington, a society heiress, did social work in Greenpoint and Williamsburg.
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: ON a pleasant residential street called Carlton Avenue in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn stands an e mpty four-story Italianate brownstone that the owner wants to sell. The owner is a 28-year-old Columbia graduate with a master's degreei n anthropology. He does not want his name disclosed or his property i dentified out of concern that this
title: REHABILITATION INCENTIVE IS AT A LEGISLATIVE CROSSROADS
